Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF GINA CLEMONS, ASSOCIATE COMMISSIONER, OFFICE OF</opening> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="GINA CLEMONS"> DISABILITY POLICY, SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Thank you, Chairman Johnson.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Chairman Johnson, Ranking Member Larson, and members of the subcommittee, thank you for inviting me to speak about our efforts to support our Nation's servicemembers and veterans. I am Gina Clemons, Associate Commissioner in the Office of Disability Policy at the Social Security Administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">I start by thanking you, Chairman Johnson, for your 29 years of dedicated service to the United States Air Force. I also thank all of the members of this Subcommittee for your service to our Nation and for your ongoing support of our servicemembers and veterans.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Social Security protects all Americans and we are proud of the help we provide to men and woman who serve and are serving our country. As an Army veteran myself, I appreciate the opportunity to highlight our targeted outreach initiatives, expedited processes, recruitment efforts, and collaborations with the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">To reach veterans, we employ a variety of outreach measures through our over 1,200 field offices. In this effort, our frontline employees are assisted by our regional public affairs specialists. In fiscal year 2017 alone, our public affairs specialists participated in more than 260 targeted outreach events with a total estimated audience of 70,000 people.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">As an example of the success of these relationships, military transition programs include information on our programs and SSA assists servicemembers in completing disability applications at military hospitals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Going through the Walter Reed Medical Center for my own military discharge, I know how daunting the process is. Having also had the privilege to see it from the other side, where I was able to take disability applications, I still recall the visible relief of servicemembers and family members, many embracing you because it was just one less thing they had to think about.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">In addition to outreach, we have a targeted website at SSA.gov where servicemembers, veterans, and their families can find information about our program, application process, and answers to common questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Providing quality and timely services is at the core of what we do for our servicemembers and veterans. At SSA, we provide disability benefits to people who cannot work because of their medical condition.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">VA considers a veteran's ability to work only in limited circumstances. VA primarily bases disability compensation on the severity of the veteran's impairments, from injuries or diseases incurred or made worse while on active duty. Different definitions require separate decisions, but we work together to strengthen both programs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">For example, through collaboration, we expedite our decisions at all levels of review for wounded warriors and veterans who have 100 Percent Permanent and Total VA rating. Since partnering with DOD in 2005 and VA in 2014, we have expedited over 200,000 claims for these wounded warriors and veterans.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">In response to interest from this Committee and the Armed Services Committee, we collaborated with DOD and VA to electronically exchange thousands of medical records. Through this process we have reduced the time it takes to receive medical records and improve the quality of our medical record extract.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">In addition to our services, we are proud of the success in recruiting and supporting veterans. We know military service helps to develop strong character and results-driven attitude. These attributes make veterans a perfect fit for our agency. Quite simply, hiring veterans is smart practice, and that is what we do.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Last fiscal year, we participated in over 200 recruitment fairs, 100 of which were at military bases or sponsored veterans organizations. At these fairs, we assembled a database of highly skilled veterans' resumes, helping us to hire 769 veterans, including 469 new colleagues with a disability like myself.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">But it is not just about hiring veterans, it is also about supporting them. For example, we created training material for our managers on military culture. We collaborated with our Veterans and Military Affairs Advisory Council to refresh our veterans employee website, which includes information on agency policies, programs, and career resources.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">In short, we are committed to providing high quality service in all aspects of our program administration and to supporting our veteran employees and their families.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Chairman Johnson, Ranking Member Larson, and members of the Subcommittee, thank you for the opportunity to describe the ways we support the men and women who have put on a uniform to serve our Nation with distinction. I extend a heartfelt thank you to all the servicemembers and veterans in attendance today.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Ms. Clemons follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Ms. Clemons "> I am happy to answer any questions. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Thank you for your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">We will turn to questions. As is customary, for each round of questions I will limit my time to 5 minutes and will ask my colleagues to also limit their questioning time to 5 minutes as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Ms. Clemons, as a 29-year veteran, I have long been committed to ensuring that our country does right by our veterans. And when it comes to our disabled veterans, it is my understanding that Social Security is processing initial claims for disabled veterans 5 to 7 days faster than for the general public. While the Social Security Administration says it is expediting these cases, that doesn't seem like it is really that much faster.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> Can you tell us more about how you are trying to expedite claims? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Chairman Johnson, thank you for the opportunity to describe our process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Veterans' and servicemembers' claims are often quite complex, with multiple chronic conditions at times and extensive medical records. It is not surprising that we see a veteran's claim with over 1,000 pieces of records in it. Despite this, we are able to expedite their claims by putting in a process at all levels of review and in each step in our program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">For example, when a veteran calls, rather than waiting the standard goal of 28 days to set an appointment, as noted, we set an appointment in 3 days. When the field office transfers that claim to the Disability Determination Services, they immediately start working the claim rather than putting it in a queue for assignment that could take a week.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Similar events happen when we have the medical consultants and the psychological consultants review the case. Rather than waiting in a queue, as soon as they are ready for review, they get reviewed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> So at each step, we are looking for ways to improve the process, and this happens at all of our levels of the program, including at the appeals level where we are able to cut the processing time in half because there are more pending claims at that level. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> You know, one thing that seems to really to make a difference is electronic health records, which can cut processing time nearly in half. And I know you work with the VA and DOD on this already. Are there any other ways to get more electronic health records for veterans? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Chairman Johnson, thank you for your support of our health IT activities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">As more veterans are receiving care outside of the VA facility, we also need to ensure that we are getting those records as expeditiously as possible.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Under our IT modernization efforts, part of that strategy includes acquiring electronic evidence from all records in an electronic format. So the more electronic records that we receive from all facilities, it will help the veterans as well as all the individuals we serve. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Okay. One thing I hear a lot from our wounded warriors is that they want to work, yet in reality, some of the policies that are supposed to help actually make things harder. You know, the Ticket to Work and Work Incentive Improvements Act of 1999 tried to help individuals with disabilities who return to work by extending their Medicare eligibility for several years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> Can you tell us what typically happens to a person returning to work who has other insurance available to them, such as through their employer, and as a result no longer want to be on Medicare? And do they have to stay on Medicare or do they have a choice? And how is this different for our wounded warriors? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Chairman Johnson, somebody who has other insurance through their employer often has the option to be on Medicare or not. This is different for our veterans, our former military servicemembers, as they are required, if they are eligible for Medicare Part B, they are required to enroll in Medicare Part B to be able to get and receive TRICARE. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> And you all follow them, I presume? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> We do, yes. We absolutely do. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Thank you for that, Ms. Clemons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">And, colleagues, as you have heard there is a quirk in the law that means these veterans aren't treated the same as everyone else. Some of these veterans may want to keep their Medicare Part B and some may not.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">But here is the problem. These veterans who want to keep access to TRICARE For Life have no choice but to stay on Medicare, which is more expensive than TRICARE, and I am not sure that is right.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">In other words, the interaction between Social Security's disability program and TRICARE program inadvertently penalizes those wounded warriors who return to work after recovering from their injuries.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">That is why I have introduced bipartisan legislation, H.R. 2243, the HEARTS Act, the Health Equity and Access for Returning Troops and Servicemembers Act. This bill would repeal the requirement that wounded warriors maintain and pay for Medicare coverage upon returning to work in order to keep access to TRICARE. It is the right thing to do.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> I will now recognize my colleague, Mr. Larson, for any questions you might have. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. LARSON">Well, thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. LARSON">And thank you, Ms. Clemons, for your testimony. I have a couple of rudimentary questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> Number one, how many veterans currently receive Social Security benefits? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Our last estimate is 1 million veterans. And we can confirm for the record that that is the current number, but 1 million. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> And what type of Social Security benefits is it that veterans and their families depend on? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Veterans can receive all of the benefits of our program, whether it is for themselves or---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> Do veterans pay into the Social Security system through their military service? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> They do indeed. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> How do Social Security disability benefits differ from VA disability compensation? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Social Security benefits are, in part, an income replacement for your inability to work. For example, if somebody has high blood pressure and depression but they are service-connected, they will get compensation for that, regardless of if they get treatment or not.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> In our program, we would look at those impairments, but if they are treated and controlled, then they wouldn't necessarily hinder their ability to work. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> But a veteran can receive both Social Security and veterans benefits as well. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Absolutely can, and many do. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. LARSON">I think it was Ronald Reagan that said facts don't lie and they are a difficult thing. I think Mr. Johnson rightly points out some of the inadequacies that exist. And one would think, based on the numbers coming through the system and the cuts in the budget and with use of modern technology, that we ought to be able to do a better job. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> So, Ranking Member Larson, with the President's budget, we will continue to hold fast in our commitment to veterans and military servicemembers. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> Yeah, but that doesn't answer my question. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> We will also be able to work our priority workloads, such as implementing our CARES plan, to bring down the pending backlog. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> So basically you are saying, this is fine, you can do without any increase, and this 10,000 baby boomers a day has no impact on Social Security, you are going to continue to operate as efficiently as possible. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> We are going to continue to look for efficiencies in our program and become more efficient where we can through our IT modernization---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> So you need no more increase, you are fine with the budget as it is? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> With the President's budget we can address our priority workloads, pending bringing down the---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> So we just went through this whole thing where we are talking about people who aren't in the military and the exhaustive time that they have to wait to get a disability claim, and you are fine with that? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Ranking Member Larson, with the President's budget, we will be able to address our workloads. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> So that is a nonanswer answer. And you insist that, well, we can do just fine with what we have. Is that right? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> Well, with $100 million extra, for every $100 million extra that we receive we can work an additional 106,000 disability claims and 51,000 hearings. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. LARSON"> So will you be able to come back to this committee next year and say, ``Given the cuts that we received in the budget and given our ability to deal with this, that we will see drastic improvement, both for our veterans and for our citizens who deserve disability and service and efficiency out of their government''? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> I will tell you that we will continue to operate---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LARSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. LARSON">That is a nonanswer. I can confirm for the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. RICE</speaker> <paragraph paraId="72" speaker="Mr. RICE">Two-point-seven million applications per year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="73" speaker="Mr. RICE">And also that your number of days to review has increased since 2012 significantly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="74" speaker="Mr. RICE"> Why is that? Isn't that the primary function of what you are doing here? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="80" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> It is, indeed. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. RICE</speaker> <paragraph paraId="81" speaker="Mr. RICE">Yeah. They were just on a TV screen in the office and allowed judges to have more hearings.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="82" speaker="Mr. RICE"> What other types of technological advances have you had to increase your efficiency and decrease these waiting times? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="83" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Congressman Rice, thank you for acknowledging the improvements we have made in our videos to work on our pending claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="84" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Other areas where we are working, we have spoken about health IT. It is not my area. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. RICE</speaker> <paragraph paraId="94" speaker="Mr. RICE">I am curious about what the fundamental underlying problem is.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="95" speaker="Mr. RICE"> Thank you, ma'am. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="96" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> I will get it to the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="97" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="98" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> Mr. Pascrell, you are recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. PASCRELL</speaker> <paragraph paraId="99" speaker="Mr. PASCRELL">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. That would include additional staff in that estimate. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. PASCRELL</speaker> <paragraph paraId="119" speaker="Mr. PASCRELL"> So if additional funding, and you pointed to a particular figure, helps you get more folks, you think you will increase. I was just going to ask one more question. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="125" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> Well, go ahead and ask it. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. PASCRELL</speaker> <paragraph paraId="126" speaker="Mr. PASCRELL">Thank you, sir.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="127" speaker="Mr. PASCRELL"> Would removing the Federal hiring freeze for the Social Security Administration improve service to veterans and those receiving Social Security benefits? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="128" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> With the hiring freeze we--you know, we are continuing to serve our veterans now. Thank you,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="134" speaker="Mr. SCHWEIKERT">Look, actually, this is one of those, maybe there is going to be a tonal quality, but I think there is a commonality of all the members on the panel, just wanting to know we are doing the right thing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="135" speaker="Mr. SCHWEIKERT">So let me start with a couple things that we are seeing in your written testimony, actually talking about electronic records and the fact that veterans that are applying for disability come to you with actually an electronic record and the fact that they move through the system somewhat more efficiently because of that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="136" speaker="Mr. SCHWEIKERT"> First, could you help me understand that efficiency of those electronic records and what that means to the population you are helping? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. CLEMONS</speaker> <paragraph paraId="137" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS">Yes, Congressman, thank you for the question.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="138" speaker="Ms. CLEMONS"> With the electronic records, that is actually a data exchange, it is an agreement that we have using the health information technology directly with the VA and DOD. And it comes in a standard format with information that helps us, the adjudicators, to make a decision. For example, it will flag us earlier about conditions that might be our most severe conditions. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. SCHWEIKERT</speaker> <paragraph paraId="145" speaker="Mr. SCHWEIKERT"> I will recap with you in just a second. I am probably past the technology, but, yes, it comes in. So somewhere here, if you ever get a chance to throw that in.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="159" speaker="Mr. SCHWEIKERT"> So with that, Mr. Chairman, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman JOHNSON</speaker> <paragraph paraId="160" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="161" speaker="Chairman JOHNSON"> Ms. Sanchez, you are recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. SANCHEZ</speaker> <paragraph paraId="162" speaker="Ms. SANCHEZ">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="163" speaker="Ms. SANCHEZ">I think all of us here today can agree on one thing, and that is we must do more to ensure that our veterans are able to retire from their service with some degree of dignity and security for their future.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="164" speaker="Ms. SANCHEZ">Social Security is the bedrock of the American retirement system, and the promise that Social Security has made is that after a lifetime of hard work, if people contribute, that seniors can retire with dignity and security.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="165" speaker="Ms. SANCHEZ">Like the general population, Social Security is there for veterans when they retire or when they experience a debilitating injury or illness that prevents them from working.
